text: Hi, this is David from MinuteEarth.

And this is urushiol; it's the molecule that
causes the painful, itchy reaction we get
when we touch poison ivy or poison oak.

But urushiol isn't poisonous; the molecule
itself doesn’t actually pose any danger
to humans.

Yet, like lots of other innocuous stuff out
there, it can hurt us by inadvertently tricking

our immune cells into thinking there’s danger,
and thus causing them to go on the attack.

When your skin comes into contact with urushiol
– or any molecule that’s attached to something

that’s not you – immune cells that patrol
just below the surface of your skin grab the

molecule with a molecule-specific set of biological
handcuffs, and bring it to a nearby immune
hub.

If the authorities there don’t recognize
the molecule, they will often make an educated

guess about how dangerous it might be, based
on the type of biological handcuffs that the

patrol cell used to grab and transport the
suspect.

If the handcuffs are the same ones used to
bind known troublemakers – like molecules

on the microbes that cause tuberculosis and
thrush – the immune authorities are likely

to label the unknown molecule as dangerous
too.

This triggers a release of toxic proteins
to flush out the area and kill everything
around.

It’s a super effective trick - if the molecule
and its pathogen are actually harmful.

But since innocent urushiol happens to be
a hydrophobic lipid - like the surface molecules

on lots of nasty fungi and bacteria - it has
the same kind of hydrocarbon tail and thus

requires the same handcuffs as lots of bad
guys.

So your body may mount an unnecessary – and
extremely uncomfortable – defense whenever
you come into contact with it.

This is the same basic biological phenomenon
behind pollen-induced sniffles and anaphylactic

shock after eating peanuts - in other words,
it's an allergy.

These harmless substances, for one reason
or another, trigger a case of mistaken identity

in some people’s immune systems, causing
their bodies to erroneously - and, well,
rashly - go on the attack.

But while most allergies only occur in a small
percent of humans, an estimated 85% of people

are allergic to urushiol, making it the most
common allergy in the world.

Which is super weird, since urushiol doesn’t
even seem to have evolved as a defense mechanism

- it’s just a sap thickener that helps seal
up damaged leaves.

And in fact, urushiol really only affects
humans and our close relatives; many other

animals snack regularly - and happily - on
poison ivy and poison oak.

We still don’t know why the urushiol allergy
is unique to us, why some of us react to it

and others don’t...or, really all that much
about allergies in the first place.
You could say we need an ivy league education.

If you’re itching for even more great content,
you’ll find it on Nebula, a platform built

by independent education-y creators like us
as a way to explore new ideas - like our own

MinuteBody series all about the weird ways
the human body works - or doesn’t.

MinuteBody - and all the other creative content
on Nebula - is brought to you with the help

of CuriosityStream, a streaming service that
brings all sorts of incredible documentaries
right to your device.

I’ve recently been making my way through
some mind-blowing David Attenborough shows,
including Light on Earth and Ant Mountain.

When you sign up at curiositystream.com/minuteearth,
for less than fifteen bucks you’ll not only

get access to CuriosityStream for an entire
year...you’ll also get to experience all

of the cool content on Nebula: stuff from
from the folks behind TierZoo, Polyphonic,
Wendover - and all-new episodes of MinuteBody.
Check it out!
